title.raw: 《五宗世家》 House of the Five Clans

meta.citation: Translation: Partial translation by Garrett M. Petersen; remaining portions by Garrett M. Petersen (2025)

sentences.zh: 孝景皇帝子凡十三人為王，而母五人，同母者為宗親。

translations.text: Emperor Xiaojing had thirteen sons who became kings, born to five different mothers. Those from the same mother were considered clan relatives.

sentences.zh: 栗姬子曰榮、德、閼于。

translations.text: Consort Li's sons were Rong, De, and A Yu.

sentences.zh: 程姬子曰餘、非、端。

translations.text: Consort Cheng's sons were Yu, Fei, and Duan.

sentences.zh: 賈夫人子曰彭祖、勝。

translations.text: Lady Jia's sons were Pengzu and Sheng.

sentences.zh: 唐姬子曰發。

translations.text: Consort Tang's son was Fa.

sentences.zh: 王夫人兒姁子曰越、寄、乘、舜。

translations.text: Lady Wang and Lady Xu's sons were Yue, Ji, Cheng, and Shun.

Emperor Xiaojing had thirteen sons who became kings, born to five different mothers. Those from the same mother were considered clan relatives. Consort Li's sons were Rong, De, and A Yu. Consort Cheng's sons were Yu, Fei, and Duan. Lady Jia's sons were Pengzu and Sheng. Consort Tang's son was Fa. Lady Wang and Lady Xu's sons were Yue, Ji, Cheng, and Shun.

sentences.zh: 河閒獻王德，以孝景帝前二年用皇子為河閒王。

translations.text: King Xian of Hejian, De, was made King of Hejian as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's second year before his reign.

sentences.zh: 好儒學，被服造次必於儒者。

translations.text: He loved Confucian learning. Even in his clothing and hasty actions, he always followed Confucian scholars.

sentences.zh: 山東諸儒多從之游。

translations.text: Many Confucian scholars from Shandong traveled to study with him.

King Xian of Hejian, De, was made King of Hejian as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's second year before his reign. He loved Confucian learning. Even in his clothing and hasty actions, he always followed Confucian scholars. Many Confucian scholars from Shandong traveled to study with him.

sentences.zh: 二十六年卒，子共王不害立。

translations.text: He died after twenty-six years. His son, King Gong Bu Hai, succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 四年卒，子剛王基代立。

translations.text: He died after four years. His son, King Gang Ji, succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 十二年卒，子頃王授代立。

translations.text: He died after twelve years. His son, King Qing Shou, succeeded him.

He died after twenty-six years. His son, King Gong Bu Hai, succeeded him. He died after four years. His son, King Gang Ji, succeeded him. He died after twelve years. His son, King Qing Shou, succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 臨江哀王閼于，以孝景帝前二年用皇子為臨江王。

translations.text: King Ai of Linjiang, A Yu, was made King of Linjiang as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's second year before his reign.

sentences.zh: 三年卒，無後，國除為郡。

translations.text: He died after three years without heirs. The kingdom was abolished as a commandery.

King Ai of Linjiang, A Yu, was made King of Linjiang as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's second year before his reign. He died after three years without heirs. The kingdom was abolished as a commandery.

sentences.zh: 臨江閔王榮，以孝景前四年為皇太子，四歲廢，用故太子為臨江王。

translations.text: King Min of Linjiang, Rong, was made crown prince in Emperor Xiaojing's fourth year before his reign. He was deposed after four years and the former crown prince was made King of Linjiang.
King Min of Linjiang, Rong, was made crown prince in Emperor Xiaojing's fourth year before his reign. He was deposed after four years and the former crown prince was made King of Linjiang.

sentences.zh: 四年，坐侵廟壖垣為宮，上徵榮。

translations.text: In his fourth year, he was convicted of encroaching on the temple grounds to build a palace. The emperor summoned Rong to court.

sentences.zh: 榮行，祖於江陵北門。

translations.text: As Rong departed, he performed farewell rites at Jiangling's north gate.

sentences.zh: 既已上車，軸折車廢。

translations.text: He had already boarded his carriage when the axle broke and the carriage was ruined.

sentences.zh: 江陵父老流涕竊言曰：「吾王不反矣！」

translations.text: The elders of Jiangling wept and whispered among themselves: 'Our king will never return!'

sentences.zh: 榮至，詣中尉府簿。

translations.text: When Rong arrived, he reported to the Commandant of Justice's office.

sentences.zh: 中尉郅都責訊王，王恐，自殺。

translations.text: Commandant Zhi Du interrogated the king, who became terrified and committed suicide.

sentences.zh: 葬藍田。

translations.text: He was buried at Lantian.

sentences.zh: 燕數萬銜土置冢上，百姓憐之。

translations.text: Tens of thousands of Yan people carried soil in their mouths to build his tomb. The common people pitied him.

In his fourth year, he was convicted of encroaching on the temple grounds to build a palace. The emperor summoned Rong to court. As Rong departed, he performed farewell rites at Jiangling's north gate. He had already boarded his carriage when the axle broke and the carriage was ruined. The elders of Jiangling wept and whispered among themselves: 'Our king will never return!' When Rong arrived, he reported to the Commandant of Justice's office. Commandant Zhi Du interrogated the king, who became terrified and committed suicide. He was buried at Lantian. Tens of thousands of Yan people carried soil in their mouths to build his tomb. The common people pitied him.

sentences.zh: 榮最長，死無後，國除，地入于漢，為南郡。

translations.text: Rong was the eldest but died without heirs. The kingdom was abolished and its territory incorporated into Han as Nanhun Commandery.
Rong was the eldest but died without heirs. The kingdom was abolished and its territory incorporated into Han as Nanhun Commandery.

sentences.zh: 右三國本王皆栗姬之子也。

translations.text: These three kingdoms were originally ruled by sons of Consort Li.
These three kingdoms were originally ruled by sons of Consort Li.

sentences.zh: 魯共王餘，以孝景前二年用皇子為淮陽王。

translations.text: King Gong of Lu, Yu, was made King of Huaiyang as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's second year before his reign.

sentences.zh: 二年，吳楚反破後，以孝景前三年徙為魯王。

translations.text: Two years after the Wu and Chu rebellion was crushed, he was moved to become King of Lu in Emperor Xiaojing's third year before his reign.

sentences.zh: 好治宮室苑囿狗馬。

translations.text: He enjoyed constructing palaces, gardens, and parks, as well as dogs and horses.

sentences.zh: 季年好音，不喜辭辯。

translations.text: In his later years he loved music but disliked literary debate.

sentences.zh: 為人吃。

translations.text: He was a glutton.

King Gong of Lu, Yu, was made King of Huaiyang as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's second year before his reign. Two years after the Wu and Chu rebellion was crushed, he was moved to become King of Lu in Emperor Xiaojing's third year before his reign. He enjoyed constructing palaces, gardens, and parks, as well as dogs and horses. In his later years he loved music but disliked literary debate. He was a glutton.

sentences.zh: 二十六年卒，子光代為王。

translations.text: He died after twenty-six years. His son Guang succeeded to the throne.

sentences.zh: 初好音輿馬；

translations.text: At first he loved music and chariots.

sentences.zh: 晚節嗇，惟恐不足於財。

translations.text: In his later years he became miserly, always fearing he lacked sufficient wealth.
He died after twenty-six years. His son Guang succeeded to the throne. At first he loved music and chariots. In his later years he became miserly, always fearing he lacked sufficient wealth.

sentences.zh: 江都易王非，以孝景前二年用皇子為汝南王。

translations.text: King Yi of Jiangdu, Fei, was made King of Runan as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's second year before his reign.

sentences.zh: 吳楚反時，非年十五，有材力，上書願擊吳。

translations.text: During the Wu and Chu rebellion, Fei was fifteen and showed great courage. He petitioned to lead troops against Wu.

sentences.zh: 景帝賜非將軍印，擊吳。

translations.text: Emperor Jing granted Fei a general's seal and sent him to attack Wu.

sentences.zh: 吳已破，二歲，徙為江都王，治吳故國，以軍功賜天子旌旗。

translations.text: After Wu was defeated, two years later he was moved to become King of Jiangdu, ruling the former Wu territory. For his military achievements, he was granted the emperor's banners.

sentences.zh: 元光五年，匈奴大入漢為賊，非上書願擊匈奴，上不許。

translations.text: In the fifth year of Yuanguang, the Xiongnu invaded Han territory on a large scale. Fei petitioned to attack the Xiongnu, but the emperor would not allow it.

sentences.zh: 非好氣力，治宮觀，招四方豪桀，驕奢甚。

translations.text: Fei was fond of physical strength and built palaces and towers. He attracted bold heroes from all directions and lived in great extravagance.

King Yi of Jiangdu, Fei, was made King of Runan as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's second year before his reign. During the Wu and Chu rebellion, Fei was fifteen and showed great courage. He petitioned to lead troops against Wu. Emperor Jing granted Fei a general's seal and sent him to attack Wu. After Wu was defeated, two years later he was moved to become King of Jiangdu, ruling the former Wu territory. For his military achievements, he was granted the emperor's banners. In the fifth year of Yuanguang, the Xiongnu invaded Han territory on a large scale. Fei petitioned to attack the Xiongnu, but the emperor would not allow it. Fei was fond of physical strength and built palaces and towers. He attracted bold heroes from all directions and lived in great extravagance.

sentences.zh: 立二十六年卒，子建立為王。

translations.text: He reigned for twenty-six years and died. His son Jian succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 七年自殺。

translations.text: He committed suicide after seven years.

sentences.zh: 淮南、衡山謀反時，建頗聞其謀。

translations.text: During the Huainan and Hengshan rebellion, Jian had heard rumors of their plot.

sentences.zh: 自以為國近淮南，恐一日發，為所并，即陰作兵器，而時佩其父所賜將軍印，載天子旗以出。

translations.text: Since his kingdom bordered Huainan, he feared that if rebellion broke out he would be annexed. So he secretly manufactured weapons while always wearing his father's general's seal and going out with the emperor's banners.

sentences.zh: 易王死未葬，建有所說易王寵美人淖姬，夜使人迎與姦服舍中。

translations.text: Before King Yi was even buried, Jian took a fancy to King Yi's favored beauty Nao Ji and sent men at night to bring her to his chambers for illicit relations.

sentences.zh: 及淮南事發，治黨與頗及江都王建。

translations.text: When the Huainan affair broke out, the investigation of accomplices implicated both Jian and King Jian of Jiangdu.

sentences.zh: 建恐，因使人多持金錢，事絕其獄。

translations.text: Jian became frightened and sent men with large amounts of gold and money to bribe officials and suppress the case.

sentences.zh: 而又信巫祝，使人禱祠妄言。

translations.text: He also trusted sorcerers and witches, sending them to pray and make false claims.

sentences.zh: 建又盡與其姊弟姦。

translations.text: Jian also committed incest with all his sisters and brothers.

sentences.zh: 事既聞，漢公卿請捕治建。

translations.text: When this became known, Han nobles requested Jian's arrest and trial.

sentences.zh: 天子不忍，使大臣即訊王。

translations.text: The Son of Heaven spared him and sent ministers to interrogate the king.

sentences.zh: 王服所犯，遂自殺。

translations.text: The king admitted his crimes and committed suicide.

sentences.zh: 國除，地入于漢，為廣陵郡。

translations.text: The kingdom was abolished and its territory incorporated into Han as Guangling Commandery.

He reigned for twenty-six years and died. His son Jian succeeded him. He committed suicide after seven years. During the Huainan and Hengshan rebellion, Jian had heard rumors of their plot. Since his kingdom bordered Huainan, he feared that if rebellion broke out he would be annexed. So he secretly manufactured weapons while always wearing his father's general's seal and going out with the emperor's banners. Before King Yi was even buried, Jian took a fancy to King Yi's favored beauty Nao Ji and sent men at night to bring her to his chambers for illicit relations. When the Huainan affair broke out, the investigation of accomplices implicated both Jian and King Jian of Jiangdu. Jian became frightened and sent men with large amounts of gold and money to bribe officials and suppress the case. He also trusted sorcerers and witches, sending them to pray and make false claims. Jian also committed incest with all his sisters and brothers. When this became known, Han nobles requested Jian's arrest and trial. The Son of Heaven spared him and sent ministers to interrogate the king. The king admitted his crimes and committed suicide. The kingdom was abolished and its territory incorporated into Han as Guangling Commandery.

sentences.zh: 膠西于王端，以孝景前三年吳楚七國反破後，端用皇子為膠西王。

translations.text: King Yu of Jiaoxi, Duan, was made King of Jiaoxi as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's third year before his reign, after the Wu and Chu Seven Kingdoms rebellion was crushed.

sentences.zh: 端為人賊戾，又陰痿，一近婦人，病之數月。

translations.text: Duan was cruel and tyrannical by nature, and moreover suffered from impotence. Whenever he approached a woman, he would fall ill for several months.

sentences.zh: 而有愛幸少年為郎。

translations.text: He had a beloved young man who served as a gentleman-in-attendance.

sentences.zh: 為郎者頃之與後宮亂，端禽滅之，及殺其子母。

translations.text: This attendant soon committed adultery with the women of the rear palace. Duan captured and executed him, along with his mother and children.

sentences.zh: 數犯上法，漢公卿數請誅端，天子為兄弟之故不忍，而端所為滋甚。

translations.text: He repeatedly violated the laws of the court. Han's nobles and ministers repeatedly requested his execution, but the emperor spared him for the sake of brotherhood. Yet Duan's offenses grew worse.

sentences.zh: 有司再請削其國，去太半。

translations.text: The officials twice requested that his kingdom be reduced, removing more than half.

sentences.zh: 端心慍，遂為無訾省。

translations.text: Duan was resentful and became extremely frugal.

sentences.zh: 府庫壞漏盡，腐財物以巨萬計，終不得收徙。

translations.text: His storehouses and treasuries all rotted and leaked, with spoiled goods worth millions. In the end he could not collect or move them.

sentences.zh: 令吏毋得收租賦。

translations.text: He ordered his officials not to collect rents and taxes.

sentences.zh: 端皆去衛，封其宮門，從一門出游。

translations.text: Duan dismissed all his guards and sealed his palace gates, going out to travel through only one gate.

sentences.zh: 數變名姓，為布衣，之他郡國。

translations.text: He frequently changed his name and surname, dressed as a commoner, and traveled to other commanderies and kingdoms.

King Yu of Jiaoxi, Duan, was made King of Jiaoxi as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's third year before his reign, after the Wu and Chu Seven Kingdoms rebellion was crushed. Duan was cruel and tyrannical by nature, and moreover suffered from impotence. Whenever he approached a woman, he would fall ill for several months. He had a beloved young man who served as a gentleman-in-attendance. This attendant soon committed adultery with the women of the rear palace. Duan captured and executed him, along with his mother and children. He repeatedly violated the laws of the court. Han's nobles and ministers repeatedly requested his execution, but the emperor spared him for the sake of brotherhood. Yet Duan's offenses grew worse. The officials twice requested that his kingdom be reduced, removing more than half. Duan was resentful and became extremely frugal. His storehouses and treasuries all rotted and leaked, with spoiled goods worth millions. In the end he could not collect or move them. He ordered his officials not to collect rents and taxes. Duan dismissed all his guards and sealed his palace gates, going out to travel through only one gate. He frequently changed his name and surname, dressed as a commoner, and traveled to other commanderies and kingdoms.

sentences.zh: 相、二千石往者，奉漢法以治，端輒求其罪告之，無罪者詐藥殺之。

translations.text: When prime ministers and officials of two thousand shi came to serve, they followed Han law to govern. Duan would seek out their crimes and report them. If they were innocent, he would poison them to death.

sentences.zh: 所以設詐究變，彊足以距諫，智足以飾非。

translations.text: He was skilled at deception and investigation, strong enough to resist remonstrance, and clever enough to disguise his faults.

sentences.zh: 相、二千石從王治，則漢繩以法。

translations.text: If prime ministers and officials of two thousand shi followed the king's governance, Han would bind them with law.

sentences.zh: 故膠西小國，而所殺傷二千石甚眾。

translations.text: Therefore Jiaoxi was a small kingdom, yet those killed and injured among the two thousand shi officials were very numerous.

When prime ministers and officials of two thousand shi came to serve, they followed Han law to govern. Duan would seek out their crimes and report them. If they were innocent, he would poison them to death. He was skilled at deception and investigation, strong enough to resist remonstrance, and clever enough to disguise his faults. If prime ministers and officials of two thousand shi followed the king's governance, Han would bind them with law. Therefore Jiaoxi was a small kingdom, yet those killed and injured among the two thousand shi officials were very numerous.

sentences.zh: 立四十七年，卒，竟無男代後，國除，地入于漢，為膠西郡。

translations.text: He reigned for forty-seven years and died. In the end he had no male heir to succeed him. The kingdom was abolished and its territory incorporated into Han as Jiaoxi Commandery.
He reigned for forty-seven years and died. In the end he had no male heir to succeed him. The kingdom was abolished and its territory incorporated into Han as Jiaoxi Commandery.

sentences.zh: 右三國本王皆程姬之子也。

translations.text: These three kingdoms were originally ruled by sons of Consort Cheng.
These three kingdoms were originally ruled by sons of Consort Cheng.

sentences.zh: 趙王彭祖，以孝景前二年用皇子為廣川王。

translations.text: King Pengzu of Zhao was made King of Guangchuan as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's second year before his reign.

sentences.zh: 趙王遂反破後，彭祖王廣川。

translations.text: After King Sui of Zhao's rebellion was crushed, Pengzu became King of Guangchuan.

sentences.zh: 四年，徙為趙王。

translations.text: After four years, he was moved to become King of Zhao.

sentences.zh: 十五年，孝景帝崩。

translations.text: After fifteen years, Emperor Xiaojing passed away.

sentences.zh: 彭祖為人巧佞卑諂，足恭而心刻深。

translations.text: Pengzu was crafty and flattering by nature, outwardly respectful but inwardly deeply treacherous.

sentences.zh: 好法律，持詭辯以中人。

translations.text: He loved legal affairs and used clever arguments to trap people.

sentences.zh: 彭祖多內寵姬及子孫。

translations.text: Pengzu had many favored consorts in his palace and many children and grandchildren.

sentences.zh: 相、二千石欲奉漢法以治，則害於王家。

translations.text: If prime ministers and officials of two thousand shi wished to follow Han law to govern, it would harm the king's family.

sentences.zh: 是以每相、二千石至，彭祖衣皁布衣，自行迎，除二千石舍，多設疑事以作動之，得二千石失言，中忌諱，輒書之。

translations.text: Therefore whenever prime ministers and officials of two thousand shi arrived, Pengzu would wear mourning clothes and personally go to welcome them. He would clear out the officials' residences and set up many suspicious matters to provoke them. If he caught them making slips of the tongue or taboo violations, he would record them.

sentences.zh: 二千石欲治者，則以此迫劫；

translations.text: When officials of two thousand shi wished to govern, he would use this to coerce and threaten them.

sentences.zh: 不聽，乃上書告，及汙以姦利事。

translations.text: If they did not listen, he would submit memorials accusing them and slander them with charges of corruption and personal gain.

sentences.zh: 彭祖立五十餘年，相、二千石無能滿二歲，輒以罪去，大者死，小者刑，以故二千石莫敢治。

translations.text: Pengzu reigned for more than fifty years. No prime minister or official of two thousand shi could complete two years in office before being dismissed for crimes—major ones died, minor ones were punished. Therefore no officials of two thousand shi dared to govern.

sentences.zh: 而趙王擅權，使使即縣為賈人榷會，入多於國經租稅。

translations.text: The King of Zhao monopolized power, sending envoys to counties to act as merchants and collect monopolies, bringing in more than the kingdom's regular taxes.

sentences.zh: 以是趙王家多金錢，然所賜姬諸子，亦盡之矣。

translations.text: Because of this the Zhao royal family had abundant gold and money, though what he bestowed on his consorts and sons also exhausted it all.

sentences.zh: 彭祖取笔江都易王寵姬王建所盜與姦淖姬者為姬，甚愛之。

translations.text: Pengzu took the favored consort of King Yi of Jiangdu that King Jian had stolen and committed adultery with—Nao Ji—as his own consort, and loved her deeply.

King Pengzu of Zhao was made King of Guangchuan as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's second year before his reign. After King Sui of Zhao's rebellion was crushed, Pengzu became King of Guangchuan. After four years, he was moved to become King of Zhao. After fifteen years, Emperor Xiaojing passed away. Pengzu was crafty and flattering by nature, outwardly respectful but inwardly deeply treacherous. He loved legal affairs and used clever arguments to trap people. Pengzu had many favored consorts in his palace and many children and grandchildren. If prime ministers and officials of two thousand shi wished to follow Han law to govern, it would harm the king's family. Therefore whenever prime ministers and officials of two thousand shi arrived, Pengzu would wear mourning clothes and personally go to welcome them. He would clear out the officials' residences and set up many suspicious matters to provoke them. If he caught them making slips of the tongue or taboo violations, he would record them. When officials of two thousand shi wished to govern, he would use this to coerce and threaten them. If they did not listen, he would submit memorials accusing them and slander them with charges of corruption and personal gain. Pengzu reigned for more than fifty years. No prime minister or official of two thousand shi could complete two years in office before being dismissed for crimes—major ones died, minor ones were punished. Therefore no officials of two thousand shi dared to govern. The King of Zhao monopolized power, sending envoys to counties to act as merchants and collect monopolies, bringing in more than the kingdom's regular taxes. Because of this the Zhao royal family had abundant gold and money, though what he bestowed on his consorts and sons also exhausted it all. Pengzu took the favored consort of King Yi of Jiangdu that King Jian had stolen and committed adultery with—Nao Ji—as his own consort, and loved her deeply.

sentences.zh: 彭祖不好治宮室、禨祥，好為吏事。

translations.text: Pengzu did not like constructing palaces and seeking auspicious omens; he liked handling official matters.

sentences.zh: 上書願督國中盜賊。

translations.text: He submitted a memorial volunteering to supervise thieves and bandits throughout the kingdom.

sentences.zh: 常夜從走卒行徼邯鄲中。

translations.text: He often went out at night with foot soldiers patrolling Handan.

sentences.zh: 諸使過客以彭祖險陂，莫敢留邯鄲。

translations.text: All envoys and travelers passing through considered Pengzu dangerous and treacherous, and none dared stay in Handan.

Pengzu did not like constructing palaces and seeking auspicious omens; he liked handling official matters. He submitted a memorial volunteering to supervise thieves and bandits throughout the kingdom. He often went out at night with foot soldiers patrolling Handan. All envoys and travelers passing through considered Pengzu dangerous and treacherous, and none dared stay in Handan.

sentences.zh: 其太子丹與其女及同產姊姦，與其客江充有卻。

translations.text: His crown prince Dan committed incest with his own daughter and full sister, and had enmity with his guest Jiang Chong.

sentences.zh: 充告丹，丹以故廢。

translations.text: Chong reported Dan, who was therefore deposed.

sentences.zh: 趙更立太子。

translations.text: Zhao established a new crown prince.

His crown prince Dan committed incest with his own daughter and full sister, and had enmity with his guest Jiang Chong. Chong reported Dan, who was therefore deposed. Zhao established a new crown prince.

sentences.zh: 中山靖王勝，以孝景前三年用皇子為中山王。

translations.text: King Jing of Zhongshan, Sheng, was made King of Zhongshan as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's third year before his reign.

sentences.zh: 十四年，孝景帝崩。

translations.text: After fourteen years, Emperor Xiaojing passed away.

sentences.zh: 勝為人樂酒好內，有子枝屬百二十餘人。

translations.text: Sheng loved wine and women by nature, with over one hundred twenty children and descendants.

sentences.zh: 常與兄趙王相非，曰：「兄為王，專代吏治事。

translations.text: He often quarreled with his brother the King of Zhao, saying: 'My brother is king and monopolizes the governance of officials.

sentences.zh: 王者當日聽音樂聲色。」

translations.text: As king, one should daily listen to music and enjoy beauty.'

sentences.zh: 趙王亦非之，曰：「中山王徒日淫，不佐天子拊循百姓，何以稱為藩臣！」

translations.text: The King of Zhao also quarreled with him, saying: 'The King of Zhongshan merely indulges in debauchery daily, does not assist the Son of Heaven in comforting and guiding the people. How can he be called a vassal minister!'

King Jing of Zhongshan, Sheng, was made King of Zhongshan as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's third year before his reign. After fourteen years, Emperor Xiaojing passed away. Sheng loved wine and women by nature, with over one hundred twenty children and descendants. He often quarreled with his brother the King of Zhao, saying: 'My brother is king and monopolizes the governance of officials. As king, one should daily listen to music and enjoy beauty.' The King of Zhao also quarreled with him, saying: 'The King of Zhongshan merely indulges in debauchery daily, does not assist the Son of Heaven in comforting and guiding the people. How can he be called a vassal minister!'

sentences.zh: 立四十二年卒，子哀王昌立。

translations.text: He reigned for forty-two years and died. His son, King Ai Chang, succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 一年卒，子昆侈代為中山王。

translations.text: He died after one year. His son Kun Chi succeeded as King of Zhongshan.
He reigned for forty-two years and died. His son, King Ai Chang, succeeded him. He died after one year. His son Kun Chi succeeded as King of Zhongshan.

sentences.zh: 右二國本王皆賈夫人之子也。

translations.text: These two kingdoms were originally ruled by sons of Lady Jia.
These two kingdoms were originally ruled by sons of Lady Jia.

sentences.zh: 長沙定王發，發之母唐姬，故程姬侍者。

translations.text: King Ding of Changsha, Fa, Fa's mother Consort Tang, formerly Consort Cheng's attendant.

sentences.zh: 景帝召程姬，程姬有所辟，不願進，而飾侍者唐兒使夜進。

translations.text: Emperor Jing summoned Consort Cheng. Consort Cheng made some excuse and did not wish to come forward. Instead she dressed up her attendant Tang Er and sent her in at night.

sentences.zh: 上醉不知，以為程姬而幸之，遂有身。

translations.text: The emperor was drunk and did not realize, thinking it was Consort Cheng and favored her, so she became pregnant.

sentences.zh: 已乃覺非程姬也。

translations.text: Only then did he realize it was not Consort Cheng.

sentences.zh: 及生子，因命曰發。

translations.text: When she gave birth to a son, he named him Fa.

sentences.zh: 以孝景前二年用皇子為長沙王。

translations.text: In Emperor Xiaojing's second year before his reign, Fa was made King of Changsha as imperial son.

sentences.zh: 以其母微，無寵，故王卑溼貧國。

translations.text: Because his mother was of lowly status and had no favor, he was made king of a poor and damp kingdom.

King Ding of Changsha, Fa, Fa's mother Consort Tang, formerly Consort Cheng's attendant. Emperor Jing summoned Consort Cheng. Consort Cheng made some excuse and did not wish to come forward. Instead she dressed up her attendant Tang Er and sent her in at night. The emperor was drunk and did not realize, thinking it was Consort Cheng and favored her, so she became pregnant. Only then did he realize it was not Consort Cheng. When she gave birth to a son, he named him Fa. In Emperor Xiaojing's second year before his reign, Fa was made King of Changsha as imperial son. Because his mother was of lowly status and had no favor, he was made king of a poor and damp kingdom.

sentences.zh: 立二十七年卒，子康王庸立。

translations.text: He reigned for twenty-seven years and died. His son, King Kang Yong, succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 二十八年，卒，子鮒鮈立為長沙王。

translations.text: He died after twenty-eight years. His son Fu You succeeded as King of Changsha.
He reigned for twenty-seven years and died. His son, King Kang Yong, succeeded him. He died after twenty-eight years. His son Fu You succeeded as King of Changsha.

sentences.zh: 右一國本王唐姬之子也。

translations.text: This one kingdom was originally ruled by a son of Consort Tang.

sentences.zh: 廣川惠王越，以孝景中二年用皇子為廣川王。

translations.text: King Hui of Guangchuan, Yue, was made King of Guangchuan as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's middle second year.
This one kingdom was originally ruled by a son of Consort Tang. King Hui of Guangchuan, Yue, was made King of Guangchuan as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's middle second year.

sentences.zh: 十二年卒，子齊立為王。

translations.text: He died after twelve years. His son Qi succeeded as king.

sentences.zh: 齊有幸臣桑距。

translations.text: Qi had a favored minister named Sang Ju.

sentences.zh: 已而有罪，欲誅距，距亡，王因禽其宗族。

translations.text: Later Sang Ju committed a crime. Qi wished to execute him, but Ju fled. The king then captured Ju's clan.

sentences.zh: 距怨王，乃上書告王齊與同產姦。

translations.text: Ju resented the king and submitted a memorial accusing King Qi of committing incest with his full sister.

sentences.zh: 自是之後，王齊數上書告言漢公卿及幸臣所忠等。

translations.text: From then on, King Qi repeatedly submitted memorials accusing Han's nobles and ministers as well as favored officials like Zhong and others.

He died after twelve years. His son Qi succeeded as king. Qi had a favored minister named Sang Ju. Later Sang Ju committed a crime. Qi wished to execute him, but Ju fled. The king then captured Ju's clan. Ju resented the king and submitted a memorial accusing King Qi of committing incest with his full sister. From then on, King Qi repeatedly submitted memorials accusing Han's nobles and ministers as well as favored officials like Zhong and others.

sentences.zh: 膠東康王寄，以孝景中二年用皇子為膠東王。

translations.text: King Kang of Jiaodong, Ji, was made King of Jiaodong as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's middle second year.

sentences.zh: 二十八年卒。

translations.text: He died after twenty-eight years.

sentences.zh: 淮南王謀反時，寄微聞其事，私作樓車鏃矢戰守備，候淮南之起。

translations.text: During the Huainan king's rebellion, Ji had heard rumors of the matter. He privately built tower chariots, arrowheads, and defensive preparations, waiting for Huainan's uprising.

sentences.zh: 及吏治淮南之事，辭出之。

translations.text: When officials investigated the Huainan affair, the evidence implicated him.

sentences.zh: 寄於上最親，意傷之，發病而死，不敢置後，於是上（問）［聞］。

translations.text: Ji was most beloved by the emperor, who was grieved by this. Ji fell ill and died, not daring to appoint an heir. Thus the emperor heard of it.

sentences.zh: 寄有長子者名賢，母無寵；

translations.text: Ji had an eldest son named Xian whose mother had no favor.

sentences.zh: 少子名慶，母愛幸，寄常欲立之，為不次，因有過，遂無言。

translations.text: His younger son was named Qing, whose mother was beloved. Ji had always wished to establish Qing, but since it was not in proper order, he remained silent despite having grounds.

sentences.zh: 上憐之，乃以賢為膠東王奉康王嗣，而封慶於故衡山地，為六安王。

translations.text: The emperor pitied him and made Xian King of Jiaodong to continue King Kang's line, while enfeoffing Qing in the former Hengshan territory as King of Liu'an.

King Kang of Jiaodong, Ji, was made King of Jiaodong as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's middle second year. He died after twenty-eight years. During the Huainan king's rebellion, Ji had heard rumors of the matter. He privately built tower chariots, arrowheads, and defensive preparations, waiting for Huainan's uprising. When officials investigated the Huainan affair, the evidence implicated him. Ji was most beloved by the emperor, who was grieved by this. Ji fell ill and died, not daring to appoint an heir. Thus the emperor heard of it. Ji had an eldest son named Xian whose mother had no favor. His younger son was named Qing, whose mother was beloved. Ji had always wished to establish Qing, but since it was not in proper order, he remained silent despite having grounds. The emperor pitied him and made Xian King of Jiaodong to continue King Kang's line, while enfeoffing Qing in the former Hengshan territory as King of Liu'an.

sentences.zh: 膠東王賢立十四年卒，謚為哀王。

translations.text: King Xian of Jiaodong reigned for fourteen years and died. His posthumous title was King Ai.

sentences.zh: 子慶為王。

translations.text: His son Qing became king.
King Xian of Jiaodong reigned for fourteen years and died. His posthumous title was King Ai. His son Qing became king.

sentences.zh: 六安王慶，以元狩二年用膠東康王子為六安王。

translations.text: King Qing of Liu'an was made King of Liu'an as son of King Kang of Jiaodong in the second year of Yuanshou.
King Qing of Liu'an was made King of Liu'an as son of King Kang of Jiaodong in the second year of Yuanshou.

sentences.zh: 清河哀王乘，以孝景中三年用皇子為清河王。

translations.text: King Ai of Qinghe, Cheng, was made King of Qinghe as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's middle third year.

sentences.zh: 十二年卒，無後，國除，地入于漢，為清河郡。

translations.text: He died after twelve years with no heirs. The kingdom was abolished and its territory incorporated into Han as Qinghe Commandery.

King Ai of Qinghe, Cheng, was made King of Qinghe as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's middle third year. He died after twelve years with no heirs. The kingdom was abolished and its territory incorporated into Han as Qinghe Commandery.

sentences.zh: 常山憲王舜，以孝景中五年用皇子為常山王。

translations.text: King Xian of Changshan, Shun, was made King of Changshan as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's middle fifth year.

sentences.zh: 舜最親，景帝少子，驕怠多淫，數犯禁，上常寬釋之。

translations.text: Shun was most beloved. As Emperor Jing's youngest son, he was arrogant and indolent, frequently committing excesses. The emperor often pardoned him leniently.

sentences.zh: 立三十二年卒，太子勃代立為王。

translations.text: He reigned for thirty-two years and died. Crown Prince Bo succeeded as king.

King Xian of Changshan, Shun, was made King of Changshan as imperial son in Emperor Xiaojing's middle fifth year. Shun was most beloved. As Emperor Jing's youngest son, he was arrogant and indolent, frequently committing excesses. The emperor often pardoned him leniently. He reigned for thirty-two years and died. Crown Prince Bo succeeded as king.

sentences.zh: 初，憲王舜有所不愛姬生長男棁。

translations.text: At first, King Xian Shun had an unfavored consort who bore his eldest son Tiao.

sentences.zh: 棁以母無寵故，亦不得幸於王。

translations.text: Because his mother had no favor, Tiao also did not receive favor from the king.

sentences.zh: 王後修生太子勃。

translations.text: Later the queen bore Crown Prince Bo.

sentences.zh: 王內多，所幸姬生子平、子商，王后希得幸。

translations.text: The king had many consorts. His favored consorts bore sons Ping and Shang. The queen rarely received favor.

sentences.zh: 及憲王病甚，諸幸姬常侍病，故王后亦以妒媢不常侍病，輒歸舍。

translations.text: When King Xian fell gravely ill, his favored consorts constantly attended to his illness. The queen, out of jealousy, did not constantly attend but would return to her chambers.

sentences.zh: 醫進藥，太子勃不自嘗藥，又不宿留侍病。

translations.text: When the physician administered medicine, Crown Prince Bo did not personally taste the medicine, nor did he stay overnight attending to the illness.

sentences.zh: 及王薨，王后、太子乃至。

translations.text: Only when the king passed away did the queen and crown prince arrive.

sentences.zh: 憲王雅不以長子棁為人數，及薨，又不分與財物。

translations.text: King Xian had never considered his eldest son Tiao as part of the family. When he died, he did not divide any property with him.

sentences.zh: 郎或說太子、王后，令諸子與長子棁共分財物，太子、王后不聽。

translations.text: Some gentlemen advised the crown prince and queen to have the various sons share property with the eldest son Tiao. The crown prince and queen did not listen.

sentences.zh: 太子代立，又不收恤棁。

translations.text: After succeeding the throne, he still neglected Tiao.

sentences.zh: 棁怨王后、太子。

translations.text: Tiao resented the queen and crown prince.

sentences.zh: 漢使者視憲王喪，棁自言憲王病時，王后、太子不侍，及薨，六日出舍，太子勃私姦，飲酒，博戲，擊筑，與女子載馳，環城過市，入牢視囚。

translations.text: Han envoys inspecting King Xian's funeral, Tiao personally stated that during King Xian's illness, the queen and crown prince did not attend. When he died, they left the residence after six days. Crown Prince Bo privately committed adultery, drank wine, gambled, played zither, raced chariots with women, circled the city through the markets, and entered prisons to inspect prisoners.

sentences.zh: 天子遣大行騫驗王后及問王勃，請逮勃所與姦諸證左，王又匿之。

translations.text: The Son of Heaven sent Grand Herald Qian to investigate the queen and interrogate King Bo, requesting to arrest Bo's accomplices in adultery and witnesses. The king hid them.

sentences.zh: 吏求捕勃大急，使人致擊笞掠，擅出漢所疑囚者。

translations.text: Officials urgently sought to capture Bo, sending men to beat and torture him, arbitrarily releasing prisoners suspected by Han.

sentences.zh: 有司請誅憲王後修及王勃。

translations.text: The officials requested execution of King Xian's queen Xiu and King Bo.

sentences.zh: 上以修素無行，使棁陷之罪，勃無良師傅，不忍誅。

translations.text: The emperor, considering that Xiu had always been immoral, allowing Tiao to frame her with crimes, and Bo had no good teachers, could not bear to execute them.

sentences.zh: 有司請廢王後修，徙王勃以家屬處房陵，上許之。

translations.text: The officials requested deposing Queen Xiu and exiling King Bo with his family to Fangling. The emperor approved.

At first, King Xian Shun had an unfavored consort who bore his eldest son Tiao. Because his mother had no favor, Tiao also did not receive favor from the king. Later the queen bore Crown Prince Bo. The king had many consorts. His favored consorts bore sons Ping and Shang. The queen rarely received favor. When King Xian fell gravely ill, his favored consorts constantly attended to his illness. The queen, out of jealousy, did not constantly attend but would return to her chambers. When the physician administered medicine, Crown Prince Bo did not personally taste the medicine, nor did he stay overnight attending to the illness. Only when the king passed away did the queen and crown prince arrive. King Xian had never considered his eldest son Tiao as part of the family. When he died, he did not divide any property with him. Some gentlemen advised the crown prince and queen to have the various sons share property with the eldest son Tiao. The crown prince and queen did not listen. After succeeding the throne, he still neglected Tiao. Tiao resented the queen and crown prince. Han envoys inspecting King Xian's funeral, Tiao personally stated that during King Xian's illness, the queen and crown prince did not attend. When he died, they left the residence after six days. Crown Prince Bo privately committed adultery, drank wine, gambled, played zither, raced chariots with women, circled the city through the markets, and entered prisons to inspect prisoners. The Son of Heaven sent Grand Herald Qian to investigate the queen and interrogate King Bo, requesting to arrest Bo's accomplices in adultery and witnesses. The king hid them. Officials urgently sought to capture Bo, sending men to beat and torture him, arbitrarily releasing prisoners suspected by Han. The officials requested execution of King Xian's queen Xiu and King Bo. The emperor, considering that Xiu had always been immoral, allowing Tiao to frame her with crimes, and Bo had no good teachers, could not bear to execute them. The officials requested deposing Queen Xiu and exiling King Bo with his family to Fangling. The emperor approved.

sentences.zh: 勃王數月，遷于房陵，國絕。

translations.text: Bo had been king for several months when he was moved to Fangling. The kingdom was extinguished.

sentences.zh: 月餘，天子為最親，乃詔有司曰：「常山憲王蚤夭，后妾不和，適孽誣爭，陷于不義以滅國，朕甚閔焉。

translations.text: More than a month later, considering that he was most beloved, the emperor instructed the officials: 'King Xian of Changshan died young. His queen and consorts were not harmonious. Legitimate and illegitimate sons slandered and contended, falling into unrighteousness and extinguishing the kingdom. I greatly pity this.'

sentences.zh: 其封憲王子平三萬戶，為真定王；

translations.text: His sons Ping and Shang were enfeoffed with thirty thousand households each, Ping as King of Sishui.'

sentences.zh: 封子商三萬戶，為泗水王。」

translations.text: Enfeoff Zi Shang with thirty thousand households as King of Sishui.'

Bo had been king for several months when he was moved to Fangling. The kingdom was extinguished. More than a month later, considering that he was most beloved, the emperor instructed the officials: 'King Xian of Changshan died young. His queen and consorts were not harmonious. Legitimate and illegitimate sons slandered and contended, falling into unrighteousness and extinguishing the kingdom. I greatly pity this.' His sons Ping and Shang were enfeoffed with thirty thousand households each, Ping as King of Sishui.' Enfeoff Zi Shang with thirty thousand households as King of Sishui.'

sentences.zh: 真定王平，元鼎四年用常山憲王子為真定王。

translations.text: King Ping of Zhending was made King of Zhending as son of King Xian of Changshan in the fourth year of Yuanding.
King Ping of Zhending was made King of Zhending as son of King Xian of Changshan in the fourth year of Yuanding.

sentences.zh: 泗水思王商，以元鼎四年用常山憲王子為泗水王。

translations.text: King Si of Sishui, Shang, was made King of Sishui as son of King Xian of Changshan in the fourth year of Yuanding.

sentences.zh: 十一年卒，子哀王安世立。

translations.text: He died after eleven years. His son, King Ai Anshi, succeeded him.

sentences.zh: 十一年卒，無子。

translations.text: He died after eleven years with no sons.

sentences.zh: 於是上憐泗水王絕，乃立安世弟賀為泗水王。

translations.text: The emperor pitied the extinction of the Sishui line and established Anshi's younger brother He as King of Sishui.

King Si of Sishui, Shang, was made King of Sishui as son of King Xian of Changshan in the fourth year of Yuanding. He died after eleven years. His son, King Ai Anshi, succeeded him. He died after eleven years with no sons. The emperor pitied the extinction of the Sishui line and established Anshi's younger brother He as King of Sishui.

sentences.zh: 右四國本王皆王夫人兒姁子也。

translations.text: These four kingdoms were originally ruled by sons of Lady Wang and Lady Xu.

sentences.zh: 其後漢益封其支子為六安王、泗水王二國。

translations.text: Later Han further enfeoffed their branch descendants as kings of Liu'an and Sishui, two kingdoms.

sentences.zh: 凡兒姁子孫，於今為六王。

translations.text: Altogether Lady Xu's descendants number six kings to this day.

These four kingdoms were originally ruled by sons of Lady Wang and Lady Xu. Later Han further enfeoffed their branch descendants as kings of Liu'an and Sishui, two kingdoms. Altogether Lady Xu's descendants number six kings to this day.

sentences.zh: 太史公曰：高祖時諸侯皆賦，得自除內史以下，漢獨為置丞相，黃金印。

translations.text: The Grand Historian says: In Gaozu's time the feudal lords all contributed taxes, able to appoint their own interior ministers and below. Only Han appointed chancellors for them with gold seals.

sentences.zh: 諸侯自除御史、廷尉正、博士，擬於天子。

translations.text: The feudal lords appointed their own censors, court ministers, and erudites, comparable to the Son of Heaven.

sentences.zh: 自吳楚反後，五宗王世，漢為置二千石，去「丞相」曰「相」，銀印。

translations.text: After the Wu and Chu rebellion, the five clans of kings generation after generation, Han appointed officials of two thousand shi for them, removed 'chancellor' and called it 'prime minister', silver seal.

sentences.zh: 諸侯獨得食租稅，奪之權。

translations.text: The feudal lords only received rent taxes, their power was taken away.

sentences.zh: 其後諸侯貧者或乘牛車也。

translations.text: Afterward the impoverished feudal lords sometimes rode ox-carts.

The Grand Historian says: In Gaozu's time the feudal lords all contributed taxes, able to appoint their own interior ministers and below. Only Han appointed chancellors for them with gold seals. The feudal lords appointed their own censors, court ministers, and erudites, comparable to the Son of Heaven. After the Wu and Chu rebellion, the five clans of kings generation after generation, Han appointed officials of two thousand shi for them, removed 'chancellor' and called it 'prime minister', silver seal. The feudal lords only received rent taxes, their power was taken away. Afterward the impoverished feudal lords sometimes rode ox-carts.
